text: Studying LLMs in Use, How Professionals Navigate, Value, and Critique AI.
Gabriel Alcaraz, Donato Reach, Tommaso Pernetti, Zoe De Vries.
This document presents early findings from the Ecologies of LLM Practices EL2MP project
which investigates how skilled professionals make sense of and integrate large language models into their daily work.

Drawing on a six-month participatory protocol involving eight master students from Science Po, we document the evolving relationship between users and LLMs through a series of scenes, recreating the feel and progression of our collective in-person sessions.
Rather than focusing on LLM capabilities in isolation, we situate their use within broader professional ecologies.
revealing how LLMs reshape work by introducing new forms of labor such as prompt crafting, error evaluation, and task discretization.
Participants oscillate between frustration and reliance, treating LLMs less as automation tools and more as alien collaborators, offering emotional reassurance, low-stake experimentation,
and bureaucratic relief.
In contrast with the dominant narratives of AI productivity, we highlight how LLMs alter the texture of work and require adaptation from users.
These results argue in favor of a shift from abstract benchmarks to situated practice-based accounts, taking into account the performances and consequences of AI systems alike.
At the core of our inquiry lie pressing interrogations.
Is there anything inherently valuable in LLM use?
Do workers value these technologies differently than managerial aspirations for optimization and cost reduction?
How do they manage their capacities and reconcile their results?
In answering these questions, we aim to reframe the discourse on generative AI by prioritizing the knowledge, expertise, and values of workers over those of its developers.

We ground our critique within actual practices and the issues that arise from them, focusing on LLM use alone, as in traditional human-computer interaction, risks reducing situated practices to mere inputs and outputs.
Instead, we situate LLM use within different professional norms and material configurations, their ecologies.
We explore where the need to prompt arises and what happens to resulting outputs, focusing not on the use of technology, but on technology in use.

We developed a participatory experimental research protocol open to reproduction and adaptation through the collaboration among sociologists, science and technology studies scholars, and design researchers.
Through a series of exercises, the protocol creates deliberate pauses in professional routines, making space and time for participants to slow down and reflect on their use of LLMs.
The full protocol is detailed in the edX for this document.
This protocol is intimated with several cohorts, each lasting six to eight months, involving a total of 40 professionals as co-inquirers.
Because tech companies market LLMs as a potential tool or a replacement for skilled knowledge workers, we focus on that same demographic

Recruiting participants trained in France's top institutions, our co-inquirers engage in regular individual and group leadings with the researchers, producing a multimodal archive—audio, photo, video, drawing, chat logs—that capture tangible experiences of LLMs in use.
We present our argument through five scenes, each inspired by a key moment in the cohort's life, combined
They follow the arc of the experiment from our very first meeting to our final discussion six months later.
Each scene adds a new layer to the inquiry, while tracing the gradual evolution of participants' thoughts, use, and relations to large language models.
